titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Dudley Fitts Papers
titlestmt.author: by Michael L. Forstrom

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Dudley Fitts Papers consists chiefly of writings and correspondence relating to the production of the first American edition of An Anthology of Contemporary Latin-American Poetry (New Directions, 1942).

langmaterial.language: Materials in English, Spanish, and French.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Dudley Fitts Papers was aquired through gifts from Dudley and Cornelia Fitts from 1941 to 1969.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

Restricted Fragile papers in boxes 17-18 may be consulted only with permission of the appropriate curator. Preservation photocopies or photographic prints for reference use have been substituted in the main files.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Dudley Fitts Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Dudley Fitts Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The Dudley Fitts Papers contains material formerly classed as Za Fitts.

bioghist.head: Dudley Fitts (1903-1968)
bioghist.p: Dudley Fitts was a poet, translator, literary critic, and educator. Fitts was perhaps best known for his translations of classical texts. He translated several works by Aristophanes, including Lysistrata (1954), The Frogs (1955), The Birds (1957), and Ladies' Day (1959) and, in collaboration with Robert Fitzgerald, he translated Euripides' The Alcestis (1936) and Sophocles' Antigone (1939) and Oedipus Rex (1949). He is also the author of Poems, 1929-1936 (1937) and editor of An Anthology of Contemporary Latin-American Poetry (1942).
Fitts was born April 28, 1903, in Boston and educated at Harvard. He taught at the Choate School from 1927 to 1941 and then served as an instructor of English at Phillips Academy from 1941 onward.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Dudley Fitts Papers consist chiefly of material relating to the production of the first American edition of An Anthology of Contemporary Latin-American Poetry (New Directions, 1942). Fitts served as editor for Spanish poetry in the bilingual anthology, selecting material and translators, and supervising and editing translations. The papers include both correspondence and writings, the bulk of which date from 1941 to 1943. There are letters with contributing authors and translators, representatives of the sponsoring agency, the Committee on Publications of the Office of the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs, and the publisher. The writings include typescript copies of poems, drafts of translations, many of which are corrected and annotated, proofs, and other materials.
In addition to the material relating to the anthology, there are letters from other writers, concerning literary matters, and drafts and proofs to translations by Fitts of several classical texts.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is organized into two series: I. Correspondence, 1928-1968. II. Writings, 1935-1967.

controlaccess.corpname: United States. Office of the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence consists chiefly of letters relating to the first American edition of An Anthology of Contemporary Latin-American Poetry (New Directions, 1942). Fitts served as editor for Spanish poetry in the bilingual anthology, selecting material and translators, and supervising and editing translations. There are both original incoming letters and carbon copies of outgoing letters, dating from 1941 to 1943, with contributing authors and translators, representatives of the sponsoring agency, the Committee on Publications of the Office of the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs, and the publisher. Contributing authors include Jorge Carrera Andrade, Alejandro Carri√≥n, Eugenio Florit, Carlos Izaguirre, Jes√∫s Lara, Rafael M√©ndez Dorich, Hip√≥lito Quell S√°nchez, and others. Translators include Angel Flores, Joseph Leonard Grucci, H. R. Hays, Langston Hughes, Rolfe Humphries, Muna Lee, Lloyd Mallan, Richard O'Connell, Donald Walsh, and others. Correspondence with authors and translators concern submissions, and some include copies of original poems, drafts of translations, and lists of corrections. Correspondence with Robert S. Benjamin, John Peale Bishop, Dudley Poore, and other members of the Office of the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs documents production of the anthology.
Other noteworthy correspondents include T. S. Eliot, Archibald MacLeish, Thomas Mann, William Somerset Maugham, Ezra Pound, and Gertrude Stein.
Correspondence is in English and Spanish.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Writings consist chiefly of material relating to the first American edition of An Anthology of Contemporary Latin-American Poetry (New Directions, 1942). Fitts served as editor for Spanish poetry in the bilingual anthology, selecting material and translators, and supervising and editing translations. Materials include typescript copies of poems, drafts of translations, many of which are corrected and annotated, proofs, and other materials. Copies of poems and drafts of translations, housed in boxes 4-7, are arranged alphabetically by author.

In addition to the material relating to An Anthology of Contemporary Latin-American Poetry , there are drafts, proofs, and other materials relating to several translations by Fitts. These translations, some done in collaboration with Robert Fitzgerald, include texts by Aristophanes ( Lysistrata , The Frogs , The Birds , and Ladies' Day ), Euripides ( The Alcestis ), and Sophocles ( Antigone and Oedipus Rex ).
